<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: try { printWriter.write("1\n"); } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
<<<explanation>>>: The problem is that you are writing string without a line break. But BufferedReader expects one of the line characters mentioned above which you are not providing. It does output the whole buffer once the end of the stream is reached though. To fix this, you need to add a line break at the end of your write method call.

Regarding your second question, you can use the following code to empty the file content and then append text multiple times:

<<<api>>>: FileWriter.write
<<<code>>>: try {
FileWriter fileOut = new FileWriter("file.txt", true);
fileOut.write(""); // empty the content
fileOut.write("ddd"); // append the first time
fileOut.write("eee"); // append the second time
fileOut.write("fff"); // append the third time
fileOut.close();
} catch (IOException e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}

This code opens the file in append mode, so you only need to open it once. Then it writes the empty string to remove the current content, followed by the desired text to be appended. Finally, it closes the file.
